You can have labs done that show results "within lab limits" and still be undermedicated. It is not a matter of the tests being wrong, it is a matter of the doctor not knowing how to read the test results.It happens all the time, and many suffer for years because their doctor does not see a flag on the result calling it low or high.Hopefully your Endo will know something about thyroids, rather than diabetes, and will see that you need an increase.You probably need a fresh ultrasound before you start asking your Endo about the need for an FNA or other tests or treatment.
Are any of the nodules large enough to be biopsied? I think this is the first step.

question: I was diagnosed with a multinodular goiter about 5 years ago.  At the time, all of my thyroid panel blood tests wereshowing values within the norm range. My symptoms at the time were: extreme fatigue, excessive fluid retention, myface and hands were staying puffy and swollen(especially around my eyes), weight gain, hair falling out, skin andfingernail changes, severe constipation, decreased urination and urine seemed darker than usual.  I kept going andcomplaining to my doctor.  He ordered an ultrasound of my thyroid.  I was called and told the results were normal. Ifinally asked if I could have a thyroid scan performed.  He agreed.  I was called and told I had a multinodular goiter.I was started on Levothyroxine 75mcg.  Symptoms got somewhat better, but not alot.  I have started having frequentproblems swallowing, especially water and tea.  I get choked alot.  I also have a sensation when I'm swallowing of a lump in the left side of my throat.  When I turn my head sharply to the left,  I have a sensation of something pushingin on my throat at the base.  My fluid retention, hair falling out, and fatigue have exacerbated again.  Now I'm havingsevere muscle pain, also.  My neck always looks red or 'sunburned' appearance.  My thyroid blood tests have remained in the norm throughout all of this.  What should I do?  Are there any specific tests I should be requesting?Should I ask for a fine needle biopsy on the nodules?  The symptoms are significantly affecting my life.  I feel likeI'm dragging a one-ton truck around on my back all day.  I feel like I'm in a fog mentally.  I forget things easily.  My doctor has talked about referring me to Mayo Clinic.  I live in Oklahoma, so that's quite a haul for me.  Is there something I need to be asking my doctor that I'm missing?  I recently got established with an endocrinologist.THANKS FOR YOUR TIME,Cooncreek 8487
